awd_titl_txt: RUI: Computational Methods for Molecular Resonances and Study of Electron-induced Reactions
awd_abstract_narration:
Professor Thomas Sommerfeld of Southeastern Louisiana University is supported by an award from the Chemical Theory, Models and Computational Methods program in the Division of Chemistry.  He develops computational methods to study the properties of negatively charged molecules called molecular anions. The presence of extra electrons (negative charges) can alter the strengths of the chemical bonds in a molecule.  A chemical bond is formed when electrons are shared between nearby atoms.  These shared electrons act like a "glue" that hold the atoms together to form a molecule. However, the presence of either too little or too much glue can weaken a chemical bond.  If the bond is weakened enough, a molecular anion can become metastable and the bond can be easily broken. Alternatively, the metastable molecular anion can undergo a rearrangement and release an electron so that it can go back to having stronger, more stable bonds. Examples of areas in which these phenomena are applied are the etching of integrated circuits, studies involving chemical reactions in the upper atmosphere, radiation damage to living tissue, and some cancer therapies.  Dr. Sommerfeld develops computer models of metastable anions. Making computer models of metastable anionic molecules is a challenge because one needs to simulate the quantum mechanical equations of motion describing all the electrons in the metastable anion, as well as all the electrons of all possible rearranged species that result from the released electron.  Dr. Sommerfeld's goal is to identify a reliable, cost-efficient method to calculate the time it takes for electron release, a critical parameter for characterizing metastable anions. The project is being carried out at Southeastern Louisiana University, a predominantly undergraduate institution. Professor Sommerfeld engages lower income and underrepresented students in research projects involving high-level theory and sophisticated computational methods. In order to introduce undergraduates to this research, he also designs educational mini-projects using standard quantum chemistry methods,so that his students can be introduced to the research area step-by-step. 


In this project Dr. Sommerfeld studies electronically metastable states, so called resonance states, or resonances. He develops first-principles methods that characterize resonances and employs these methods to study electron-induced reactions. Computing both the energy and lifetime of a resonance is a challenging task for quantum chemistry because it combines an electron-scattering phenomenon with an electron-correlation problem. Dr. Sommerfeld pursues objectives that aim at improving the accuracy and reliability of one of the existing methods used to compute the energy of resonances and he pursues more specific projects aimed at implementing a set of reliable methods in systematic steps.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Benefits for educator development.

As a professor at a primary-undergraduate institution, the PI's first area of responsibility is classroom teaching with research following as a fairly close second. Yet, it is only through grants that a cutting edge research program can be maintained program that may not yield results and publications at the same rate as programs at research universities typically do, but still at the same quality. Having an active research program helps keeping an open mind, not only in research, but also in teaching: Keeping up with recent developments in the subject area and with new learning methods.

Benefits for the undergraduate research program at Southeastern.

It is thoroughly established that students benefit greatly from engaging into undergraduate research. However, it is essential that the research is real on not merely educational. Students sense the difference immediately and will engage far more deeply when the expectations of their work are not set at a normal course level, but for publishable quality.

In particular, at Southeastern 96.5% of 13,500 students come from Louisiana, a state which is ranked 50 out of 51 in poverty level with 19.7% of people living under the poverty line. In 2021, 19% of our students were first-generation college students, 32% identified as minorities and 62.9% were female.

Unfortunately, Southeastern does not collect statistical information according to the definitions used by the NSF, however, in view of the data available it is probably safe to say that ~70% of our students come from groups underrepresented in the physical sciences. Even more, it is the PI experience that many Southeastern students have not ventured far beyond this region, and that even attending a regional meeting in another state is vastly expanding their horizons.

Specifically, seven undergraduate students were involved in the PI research for a total of 12 student-semesters. Two students presented a total of four posters at meetings and one student earned two co-author ships on papers.

Benefits from the research itself.

As a quantum chemistry project with both method development and application components, the research undertaken is highly interdisciplinary with chemical, physical, and scientific computing aspects.

The topic itself are negatively-charged molecular ions, so called anions, in particular, temporary anions and non-valence anions. As their name suggests, temporary anions are unstable: They possess a typical lifetime, but will decay into a neutral molecule and a free electron similar to the radioactive beta-decay. Non-valence anions are stable, but the excess electron is only weakly bound and occupies a spatially extended non-valence orbital.

The most tangible outcome of the research is represented by eight published papers. Two of these papers describe computational protocols for computing energy and lifetime of temporary anions. Two papers address fundamental questions regarding electron-binding motifs for specific classes of anions. Moreover, four papers describe findings from collaborative projects with experimental groups at national and international universities, where we complemented the experimental data with computations and models.

Benefits for enhanced infrastructure .

The proposal enabled the PI to maintenance his Linux computer cluster updating two work nodes and to replace aging PCs used by students to log into the Linux cluster.
